Have a look on the Japanese table manners
Two side splitted chat UI for communicate with Japanese
• The Japanese eat at low dining tables and sit on a cushion placed on tatami floor (a reed-like mat)
• If there is tokonoma in the room (a built-in recessed space), guests sit in front of it. The host sits at the middle of the table on one side.
• In restaurants and bars a hot steamed towel (“oshibori”) is offered so you can clean your hands. Do not wipe your face with the towel.
• A meal begins once the main guest, family member or waitress makes a gesture to start eating.
• To finish the meal, one might say “gochisosama deshita”, which means, “thank you for the meal”.
• When not in use, place your chopsticks on a “hashioki”, or chopstick stand.
• Food should always be eaten in one bite, so try not to bite food into smaller bits.
• When drinking alcoholic beverages, it is customary to serve each other rather than pour your own drink.
• When consuming miso soup, drink the soup as if it were a cup, and then fish out the solid bits using chopsticks.
• Placing empty clam shells on another plate or in the lid of a bowl is considered impolite.
• Pour the amount of soya sauce you will use into the shallow.
• When eating sushi, do not mix wasabi into your soya sauce bowl.
• If pouring a drink, the hand holding the bottle should always pour forward.
• Tea ceremonies require strict adherence to rules designed to promote tranquility.
• When you’ve finished your meal, return the table to how it looked in the beginning.
• Generally speaking, the person who invited everyone pays for the meal.
